loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran is 40-year-old lady. She lives with her family in a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

Sugran is a vigorous lady. She runs her own sewing business. She learnt the sewing skills from her mother. She has been managing this business for more than 15 years. Now she has become an expert and can sew designer and non-designer dresses very easily. She does this work to cover the expenses of her family.

Sugran is applying for a loan to buy wheat to expand her husband’s wheat-selling business. She has five other ladies in her loan group. Khursheedan and Hanifan and Sakina each want a loan to buy timber for their timber-selling businesses. Meena wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zahida parveen wants a loan to buy fruit for her fruit-selling business.

Samina wants to take out a loan for her husband's timber-selling business and Saima Kanwal wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits & vegetables to expand her husband's business.

texts.en:
Anayat wants a loan to buy wheat for her wheat-selling business. Anwar wants a loan to buy mason's tools. Shahnaz akhtar wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Hamidan wants a loan to buy bangles for her bangle-selling business. Buhran wants a loan to buy a new donkey cart for loading.

Nasira is the group leader of the above-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. Nasira's husband's name is M. S. and he has a fruit-selling business. He has been in this business for over 10 years. He sells his fruit on a fruit cart going to different areas. Nasira is a housewife but she also helps him arrange the fruit on his cart every morning. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruit to expand her husband's fruit-selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit for resale

loans.name: Mary Wangari

texts.en:
Mary is 50 years old and married with three children. She has been a landlady for the past 20 years. She constructs rental houses and gets tenants who pay rent. She lives in Kangemi, which is a prime area for her houses since it has a large population.

Mary got to know about KADET through a marketing activity carried out by the organization. She had never borrowed from another institution and this is her first loan with KADET.  With this loan, Mary wants to renovate the houses and even buy a lorry to carry sand, gravel and other building materials.

loans.use: to buy sand, gravel and other building materials to construct more houses

loans.name: Sarah Cherop

texts.en:
Sarah Cherop N. is 39 years old, married to Ernest Tuwei and blessed with four children. She lives in Lemoru on the outskirts of Eldoret and does maize farming. She has been farming for three years now. Most of her customers are her neighbors.

This is her first loan from KADET after she was introduced to KADET by an existing client. Sarah will use the entire loan for farming (planting maize). She will buy fertilizer and maize seeds. 

Her goal is to educate her children and expand her farming so that she can increase her family's income and improve their living standard.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and maize seeds for planting

texts.en:
Sophia is 28 years old, married and the mother of two children. She operates a cereals stall in the Kangemi market. This is her primary business, which she has been doing for the last two years. Her clients are mainly people from Kangemi and its environs. The Kangemi area is pretty busy in terms of business and has a high population, most of whom are low-income earners.

Sophia stays at Kangemi together with her family. Her two children are pretty young; they are just starting school. Her husband, Isaac, is also doing a business. 

She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her second loan with KADET. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET.  Sofia wants to add more stock of cereals like beans, soya beans, peas, green gram (mung bean) and others amounting to Kshs 30,000.

She hopes and desires to give her family a good life.

loans.use: To buy more cereals like peas, beans, green grams and others

loans.name: Susan Makena

texts.en:
Susan is 30 years old and a married mother of two children. She stays at Kangemi together with her family. Her husband, Isaac, is working as a manager. 

Susan operates an MPESA (mobile money transfer) business in the Kangemi market. This is her primary business, which she has been doing for the last two months. Her clients are mainly people from Kangemi and its environs. Kangemi area is pretty busy in terms of business and has a high population, most of whom are low-income earners.

She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her second loan with KADET. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET. She will use the loan advance to buy more phone accessories.

She hopes and desires to operate a more stable business so as to increase the family income.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone accesories.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 70 years old and married with six children. His primary business is animal and crop farming which he has been doing for a number of years. He sells milk to his neighbors. James has also built some structures that he rents out as residential houses and shops. He lives in Kinoo which is a busy business center on the outskirts of Nairobi. This is his fourth loan with KADET — his only source of financing. James wants to add more structures so that he can rent them out and get more income. He hopes to raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To build more shops and houses to rent.

loans.name: Jaqueline Wanjiku

texts.en: Jacqueline is a single mother of two children. She lives in Uthiru with her children and operates a guided group tour business — a business she has had for a while. The business arranges for tourists to visit various sites and includes mountain climbing, camping and safaris within Kenya. She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her second loan with them. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET. With this loan, she wants to do marketing for her business so that she can get more customers and increase her revenue.

loans.use: To market her business through advertisements, posters, etc.

loans.name: Ndamaiyu Damaris

texts.en: Damaris is 38 years old and married with three children. She has operated a green grocery stall at the Kinoo trading center for some time. She also sells cooked beans to her neighbors and those passing by. She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her sixth loan with them, having had no previous credit history. With this loan, she wants to pay school fees for her son Edward who is in class five at the primary school. Damaris hopes to put all her children through school.

loans.use: Damaris plans to pay school fees for son Edward

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline A. is a 37 year old enterprising widowed mother of two children ages 5 and 15 years old.  She has been operating a poultry business for the last two years in Siaya, a town located in the western part of Kenya along the shores of Lake Victoria.  Magdaline buys chickens in large quantities and supplies them to hoteliers in Siaya town. A good contact with the hoteliers has seen her maintain a ready and steady demand for poultry meat. 

Magdaline is taking her first loan from KADET Ltd and she intends to use the funds to purchase more chickens for sale since there is demand. She intends to maintain a good credit history so that she might be considered for a second loan. Her desire is to get a Kiva lender, through KADET Ltd., to enable her to take the business to another level of excellence.

She aspires to diversify her business by opening a retail shop because she feels that would increase her income level.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale.

loans.name: Susan Wangari

texts.en:
Susan is 38 years old and the single mother of three children. She operates a small shop at Kinoo trading center where she sells things like curry powder, salt, sweets and the like. This is her primary business which she has been doing for one year. Her customers are mainly passersby and people around the bus terminus.

Susan was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her sixth loan with KADET. She has not borrowed from any other financial institution apart from KADET. She will restock her retail shop with some of the things which are currently running low like salt, sweets and flour. Her business is still very young and small so she hopes that with this loan she will be able to add more stock and grow it substantially.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Eliud Dzombo

texts.en:
Eliud is a 40-year-old man who is separated and has two children (a 2-year-old boy and a 4-year-old girl). He lives in Sabaki-Malindi.

He is in the motorcycle-transport business, where he targets Malindi residents. His one-year-old business earns him about 3,000 Kenyan shillings a month. 

He has applied for a loan from KADET, which he will utilize to buy spare motorcycle parts. With the extra income from this loan, Eliud plans to have a dairy cow on his plot of land as well as acquire a tuk tuk (taxi).

A quiet and hardworking man, he dreams of educating his children to the tertiary level.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for the motorcycle

loans.name: Zipporah Wanjiru

texts.en:
Zipporah is a 48-year-old mother of four sons and two daughters between the ages of 7 and 31. Zipporah has been selling clothes for the past 30 years. She describes herself as a very hardworking businesswoman. 

Zipporah has been able to bring up her children single-handedly. She was introduced to KADET through marketing outreach in Thika town, her home area. She says that she has benefited from KADET and was able to acquire a motorcycle through a KADET asset loan which her son uses to offer transport services and support his family. She plans to purchase more clothes stock with the loan she has applied for. She is servicing her fifth loan with KADET. Zipporah intends to buy a piece of land with the extra profit generated from the business.  Her hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and build her own house.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes stock

loans.name: Joseph Mwangi

texts.en:
Joseph is a 39-year-old man, married to Millicent, and they have one son. He lives in Majengo-Malindi and he operates a garage. He has been in the business of vehicle repair for 12 years and makes a monthly profit of 15,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). Joseph also provides motorcycle transport services. His customers include matatu (minibus) owners, tuk tuk  (a motorcycle pulling a passenger trailer) drivers and owners of personal vehicles.

Joseph's in his third loan cycle with KADET and was introduced to KADET by a friend. With this loan he plans to use 50,000 KES to buy garage spare parts and 20,000 KES to service old motorbikes. He plans to buy a plot of land and build a residential house with the extra earnings he will get from this loan. A hardworking man, Joseph dreams of comfortably seeing his child educated.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for a garage and to service old motor bikes

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 65 year old widowed woman with four grown up children. She is in the business of selling food in Kisumu Ndogo-Malindi where her clients are  school children and teachers from the area. She has been in this business for the last six years and gets 14,000 KES a month in profit. Mary also does tailoring on the side.

She was introduced to KADET by her daughter who was in KADET at the time Mary joined and had borrowed from a bank previously. With this loan she plans to add tailoring materials for her shop with 30,000 KES, upgrade her food stall and stock supplies such as flour and sugar with 20,000 KES.

With the extra income from this loan she plans to invest in her garden. A very independent woman, Mary dreams of owning a vehicle.

loans.use: Upgrade food kiosk, add stock and add materials for tailoring shop.

loans.name: Susan Halima

texts.en:
Susan is a 29 year old woman married to Mohemed.  They have two children. She is in the business of selling water in Kisumu Ndogo-Malindi where she targets households within the area. Her business is four years old and she gets a monthly profit of 8,000 KES. Apart from the water business, Susan also sells charcoal as a secondary business.

Susan was introduced to KADET by a friend and this is her first loan. She will utilize this loan by adding stock of charcoal worth 5,000 KES and purchase water pipes as well as add a third tap to boost her business with the other 5,000 KES. With the extra profit, she plans to complete rental houses at her plot.

A hardworking woman, Susan hopes to own a big business specializing in charcoal.

loans.use: Add stock of charcoal, purchase water pipes and add another tap

loans.name: Purity Kadzo

texts.en:
Purity is 30 years old and married to Emmanuel, who is a newspaper vendor.  They have three children. Her business of selling food, from which she gets a monthly profit of 12,000 KES, is two years old and is located at Kisumu Ndogo-Malindi. 

Purity was introduced to KADET by a friend and this is her first loan. She will use 5,000 KES of this loan to add packets of flour and 5,000 KES to add furniture for the cafe. If this loan boosts her business, she will buy a plot with the extra profit. 

A hardworking woman, Purity dreams of building a personal residential home.

loans.use: To purchase flour and add furniture to cafe

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 46 years old and married to Martha Wanjiru, a businesswoman. He has built some rental houses in Kangemi where they also live. This is his primary business and he has been running it for the last two years now. Kangemi is a busy and highly populated area so these houses are in demand. Besides this, he offers wielding services for some extra income for the family. 

Michael got to know about KADET through some friends who were already members. This is his first loan with KADET although he has borrowed from other financiers before. He wants to buy materials to construct a two-bedroom iron-sheet building to add to what he already has.

Michael plans to buy another plot and build some more houses to improve his family’s living standards.

loans.use: To buy materials to construct a two-bedroom iron-sheet building

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas M. is 24 years old, is married, and is the mother of one child. She is in the business of selling fish in the Kongowea market and has been in her business for one year now.

Dorcas is borrowing her first loan from KADET and she plans to purchase more fish with the money. Kongowea is a busy market and thus she has been getting good profits.

Dorcas hopes to one day supply the fish in bulk to other towns.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Zahria Ramadhan

texts.en:
Zahria is a 36-year-old woman who is married to Rama with whom she has three children.

Zahria operates a food kiosk in Kisumu Ndogo, Malindi, where her target customers are mainly people working on construction sites. Her business is four years old and she earns a monthly profit of Ksh 12,000. 

Zahria was introduced to KADET by a friend and has not borrowed from another institution before. She plans to utilize this loan by buying furniture for her cafe with Ksh 6,000 and adding stock of supplies such as flour and sugar with Ksh 4,000. 

With the extra profit from this loan, Zahria plans to open a charcoal business. A hardworking woman, she hopes to build her own rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase furniture and supplies for her cafe

loans.name: Ayub Kanithi

texts.en:
Ayub Kanithi N. operates a hardware shop at Muguga trading center. The shop is strategically situated along the busy highway. He has been doing this as his primary business for the last two years now.

Ayub is 25 years old, married and a father of one child. His wife Jacqueline is a business woman.

Ayub learned about KADET through some friends who were already members. He will be accessing his second loan with KADET and has not borrowed from other financiers.

Ayub wants to add more stock in his hardware shop. Although Ayub’s hardware shop is fairly new he hopes to relocate it to a bigger and more spacious building. This will enable him to stock more items frequently needed by his customers.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his hardware shop.

loans.name: John Njoroge

texts.en:
John is 40 years old, married and a father of four children. His primary business is operating a taxi in Westland’s which is a high class suburb in Nairobi.

Besides this he is a farmer practicing small scale farming at his home in Rironi about 20 km from Nairobi town. He also has rental houses which bring him additional income. His wife Nelly helps him with the farming.

He learned about KADET through some friends who were already members. This is his first loan with KADET; he has borrowed from other financiers before. With this loan, John plans to buy a dairy cow and in the future he hopes to buy his own car since the one he uses is hired.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow worth 40,000 KES

loans.name: Lucy Wambui

texts.en:
Lucy Mambui M. is 38 years old and a married lady. She sells clothes in the Westlands market within Nairobi. This market is busy and receives customers regularly. She has been doing this as her primary business for three years.

She was introduced to KADET by an existing member and this is her first loan with KADET. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET.

Lucy hopes that with this loan she will be able to add more clothes stock and grow her business substantially.

loans.use: She will use the entire amount to restock her business by buying more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael O. L. is a 36-year-old married man with two children who are both in primary school.

Michael runs a retail shop in Onyalo residential estate, located in Migori along the shores of Lake Victoria. His clientele comes from the estate and other surrounding settlements. His wife, Christine, operates a salon business in Migori town.

Michael has a good credit history with KADET and it is for this reason that he has been awarded a fourth loan to boost his business which he has been operating for the last sixteen years. He will use the loan to buy more household items like cooking fat, milk and other items for sale. He hopes to get Kiva lenders to enable him to steer the growth of his current business and even diversify to wholesale.

Apart from diversifying his business, Michael’s other dream is to use the income generated to educate his children to higher levels of education.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O. is a thirty-nine-year-old industrious lady who is married to Mr. Charles O., a clerical officer. They have seven children with the last-born aged nine years. Rose has been selling cereals for the last two years in Migori town.

Rose learnt about KADET through a friend who was already a member. She is taking her second loan from KADET and she hopes to use the money to buy more maize to sell. She hopes to reap more income because there is demand for cereals in Migori town at the moment.

Rose’s dream is to open a bigger and more spacious store for storing her cereal stock since her current storage area is not big enough. She also plans to expand her dairy farming business and benefit from the demand for milk in Migori town.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize to sell

loans.name: Benson Wilsham

texts.en:
Benson Wilsham is a carpenter in Bukura town. He is married to Risper Mapesa and they have two children aged 8 and 3 years.

Benson has been in the carpentry business for the last four years and has been able to meet the family expenses out of the profits made.

He is taking his first loan from KADET and he intends to pay it well without default. Benson hopes the loan will enable him to expand his business by buying more timber, timber glue, and nails.

His future dream is to expand his business into wholesale and also to buy some latest carpentry machines in the market to enable him to work fast and efficiently.

loans.use: To buy timber and nails.

loans.name: Flora Wambui

texts.en:
Flora Wambui K. is a 67 year-old widowed woman. She is blessed with five sons and two daughters, all adults. She has operated a dairy goat farming business for the past 30 years. Flora also sells charcoal and cereals as other sources of income.

She was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She has applied for a loan which she plans to use to purchase charcoal and cereals like maize and beans for resale.

With the extra profit generated from the business Flora intends to buy a water tank. Her hopes and dreams are to expand her business and employ more people.

Flora is a widowed old woman and very hardworking. She currently attends adult classes at a school near her home. She says she wants to learn to write so that she can be able to sign documents.

She also takes care and educates a grandchild whose mother just disappeared from home. Flora describes herself as a visionary and hardworking woman.

loans.use: To purchase cereals like maize and beans

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William M. is a 24 year-old married man from Kakamega town in Western Kenya. He is married to Josephine who is a tailor in Kakamega and they have a 2 year-old daughter.

William sells clothes for both genders in Kakamega market and he is taking his second loan after successfully paying his first loan without default. He plans to use the loan to purchase readymade clothing and blankets for resale.

His future dream is to diversify his business to dairy farming. He therefore hopes to buy a dairy cow to achieve this dream. In addition, William wants to buy a plot of land and build a permanent house for his family.

loans.use: To buy readymade clothing and blankets to sell.

loans.name: Bentictor

texts.en:
Bentictor A. is a 42-year-old married man with three children between 24 and 22 years old. The children have all completed their high school level of education. Bentictor runs a butchery business in Kakamega town, Western Kenya. He sells predominantly beef products due to their popular demand in the area. 

Bentictor is taking his first loan from KADET Ltd and he intends to maintain a good repayment history, since this is a prerequisite for subsequent loans. He plans to purchase three cows and then slaughter them for his butchery business. 

He has great plans to improve his standard of living. He intends to diversify his business to dairy and poultry farming. This is because there is a high demand for poultry products like eggs and poultry meat. Bentictor also plans to invest in the passenger transport business (locally known as a Matatu business).

loans.use: To buy cows to slaughter

loans.name: Entike

texts.en:
M. is 42 years old and married with four children.  He is a livestock farmer who buys cattle to fatten then sell. He has been in the business for a period of five years, earning a monthly profit of about 40,000 Kenya shillings.

He was introduced by a KADET client. He has never borrowed from another Micro Finance Institution before. He wants to use the loan to buy more cattle to fatten.

He hopes to invest in hybrid cows and goats to increase his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy goats, sheep and cows to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Wasinga Oloo

texts.en:
Wasinga is 48 years old, a tailor and married to Joanes. They have one son and five daughters between 7 years and 23 years, respectively. 

She was introduced to Kadet through her friend, an existing Kadet client. Wasinga has been in the tailoring and dress making business for the past four years. She plans to boost her business by purchasing more fabric to make more clothes for her clients. She has no credit history with any other MFI or Bank. 

Wasinga intends to increase her stock with the extra profit expected from the business. She hopes and dreams of buying more machines and employing another staff member. She describes herself as a Christian who is honest, hardworking and loves people .

loans.use: To purchase more fabric

loans.name: Jane Wanjiku

texts.en:
Jane is 56 years old, a farmer and a processor of amaranth. She is married to Harrison and they have three daughters and three sons between 15 years and 31 years of age. 

She was introduced to Kadet through World Visions Kenya farmers Seminar. Jane has been doing farming and processing amaranth for the past six years. She also does dairy farming as her other source of income.  With the loan she has applied for, Jane plans to increase her stock in order to progress in farming and processing of amaranth. 

She intends to expand the business and supply the product throughout the country. Her hopes and dreams are to grow her business and be the greatest supplier of amaranth in Kenya and outside. Jane describes herself as a very hardworking lady and ambitious.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Edith Waithira

texts.en:
Edith is 34 years old, married to Boniface and they have one son and two daughters between eight years and 15 years of age, respectively. Edith operates a green grocery business. Edith has been running the green grocery business for the past 15 years. She also does farming as her other source of income.

She was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She plans to add cereal stock like maize, beans and green grams. Edith intends to purchase a piece of land with the extra profit generated from the business. 

Her hopes and dreams are to open a big wholesale cereal store. She describes herself as a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy maize, beans and green grams to resell

loans.name: Rose Wanjiru

texts.en:
Rose Wanjiru N. is 55 years old and a medical practitioner married to James who is a retired doctor. They have one son and two daughters aged 20, 32, and 37 years respectively. Rose has been operating a Medical Clinic for the past 17 years. She also does farming as her other source of income.

Rose was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. She is servicing her second loan with Kadet. She plans to expand her business and offer more drugs with the loan.

Her main intention is to construct a childrens clinic on her piece of land with the extra profit generated from the business. Her future hopes are to buy another piece of land and build residential houses.

Rose says that she is a strong lady, though sometimes she goes through challenging moments especially when she treats patients who either pay her little or just promise to settle the full amount later but later breach the contract. Others don’t pay anything, but she encourages herself and continues with her business.

Rose describes herself as a hardworking lady who is positive about life, loves to counsel people, attends to her patients and helps the needy in the society.

loans.use: To expand business and add more drugs.

loans.name: Patrick Thuo

texts.en:
Patrick Thuo K. is 45 years old and a farmer. He is married to Esther who is also a farmer and they have three sons and one daughter between 4 and 12 years of age.

Patrick has been doing farming for the past 10 years; he also does dairy goat farming and poultry keeping as other sources of income.

He was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet member. He is servicing his second loan with Kadet. Patrick plans to add farming products and to grow kale and tomatoes with this loan.

He intends to expand the small general shop he owns with the extra profit generated from the business. His hopes and dreams are to expand his general shop to a wholesale shop.

Patrick has been able to educate his children with the income he makes from farming. He hopes to be able to educate them through university level. He describes himself as an honest and hardworking man.

loans.use: To add new farming products.

loans.name: Gachanja

texts.en:
Gachanja is 67 years old and a dairy farmer. He is blessed with one son and two daughters. He has been doing dairy farming for the past 10 years.

Gachanja was introduced to Kadet through marketing outreach in his hometown Gatundu. He plans to buy another dairy cow with the loan he has applied for. 

Gachanjas’s main intent is to buy more dairy cows with the extra profit generated from his business. His hopes and dreams are to become a famous dairy farmer. He describes himself as a hardworking dairy farmer.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow.

loans.name: Jane Wanjiru

texts.en:
Jane Wanjiru is a 36 year old mother of one child. She lives in Kongowea in the coastal city of Mombasa. 

Jane is in the business of selling second-hand clothes in the busy Kongowea market and her business is one year old. Her main customers are the residents of Mombasa who frequent the Kongowea market.

Jane is borrowing her first loan from KADET and with the money she plans to increase her stock of second-hand clothes locally know as mitumbas. 


She hopes to go wholesale in the business in future.

loans.use: To purchase more second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Lydiah Wanjiku

texts.en:
Lydiah is 56 years old, single, and has two children. She has been selling cereals in a market in the Nairobi region for about 10 years. Her business is in a prime area because of the surrounding population and its accessibility.

Lydiah found out about KADET through a friend. This is her first loan with KADET, and she has not borrowed from other institutions before. Lydiah wants to use 30,000 KES to buy more cow peas, green grams, and other cereals for her business, so she can earn a better income to support her family. She will use the remaining 50,000 KES to support her son's music recording business.

loans.use: To buy more cereals for her business.

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia V. is 57 years old from the Sichirai area of the town of Kakamega. She is married to Naftali Ambasa who is a vehicle mechanic. They have four children with the eldest being 37 years.

Julia runs a dairy farming business. She owns a lot of dairy cows and sells the milk to her clients in the Sichirai area. She has been in this business for the last six years. The sky is the limit for her, as she anticipates a lot of growth in her business.

This is Julia's second loan, with which she plans to buy one more dairy cow and fertilizer for her farm crops. The demand for milk in the area has caused her dairy business to grow. She therefore hopes to increase her income with an additional dairy cow. She hopes to find a lender through KADET to help her boost her business.

Her dream is to build a permanent residence for her family.

loans.use: To buy one dairy cow.

loans.name: Wycliffe Ashibende

texts.en:
Wycliffe Ashibende is an industrious man who is 56 years old. He is married to Jane, a farmer. They have three children: The oldest is 34 years old, while the youngest is 17 years old.

Wycliffe has been in the tailoring and dressmaking business for the last ten years. He feels that the speed of growth of his business would have been faster if he had received access to financing during the start up of his current business.

He is requesting his first loan from KADET. He intends to use the loan to purchase materials for the preparation of male suits, which are in demand in his area, and then use the remaining part of the loan to purchase materials to make other ready-made clothing.

Wycliffe aspires to diversify his business to include the wholesale production of clothing for both men and women.

loans.use: To buy materials for dressmaking.

loans.name: Kezia

texts.en:
Kezia K. is a fifty-one year old lady. She is married to Basil Atenya, a farmer, and they have three children between the ages of 35 and 18 years. She has been running a small cafe in Shibuye market, Kakamega town for the last six years. The income she generates from this business has played a great part in uplifting her living standards. 

Kezia sells mainly cooked food and refreshments, and the quality meals and drinks she serves keep her customers coming back. Her clients are mainly shoppers in Shibuye market.

This is her third loan from KADET Ltd and she intends to use the money to buy more foodstuffs like baking flour, sugar and maize flour.

She aspires to purchase and develop a plot of land, where she can construct her residential home. She also wants to contribute to less fortunate members within her locality like orphans.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: Peter Njuguna

texts.en:
Peter, a farmer, is 43 years old. He is married to Judy and they have one son and three daughters; aged 2 ½ years, 6 years and 12 years respectively. Peter has been  farming for the past eight years.

Peter was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client. He has applied for a loan and plans to buy a dairy cow. With the extra profit generated from the business he intends to buy more dairy cows. 

He hopes to be a reliable dairy farmer and he describes himself as a hardworking and ambitious businessman.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anastasia Wanja

texts.en:
Anastasia is 48 years old and a farmer. She is blessed with one daughter and two sons, aged 10, 15 and 20 years respectively. 

Anastasia was introduced to Kadet through a business seminar at Gatundu, her home town. She has been doing farming for the past five years and also operates a general retail shop as her other source of income. She plans to add another dairy cow with the loan she has applied for. With the extra profit, she intends to buy more dairy cows.

Anastasia hopes to grow her farming business, retail shop and dairy farming, and to purchase a chaff cutter. She describes herself as a hard-working farmer.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow

loans.name: Josepina

texts.en: Josepina Q. is from the village of Northern Pob., Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 62 years old. Josepina is married. To make a living, Josepina operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for her business comes from selling daily-use products, such as eggs, noodles, some snack food, candies, canned goods, rice, sugar, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Josepina has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,600 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Josepina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josepina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Josepina is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Josepina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Fe

texts.en: Mary Fe D. is from the village of Boundary Sapang, Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old. Mary Fe is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Fe owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for her business comes from providing motor-transport services to local community members. Mary Fe is just starting this business. In 2009, Mary Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Mary Fe is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the second loan taken out by Mary Fe from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Hierng

texts.en: Mrs. S. has a life partner in her husband who is a firewood seller. They both reside in a medium wooden house located in Kompong Tom, a province of Cambodia. The couple has three school-aged kids who are also under their care. In order to earn a daily income, S. goes to buy groceries in bulk from her supplier in the market and she sells the groceries to her nearby villagers to raise cash. In a day, she is able to generate at least $3, which she uses to feed her family. Beside her grocery business, S. and her husband always take time to plant various kinds of crops during farming season. S. plans to buy a piece of a good farmland but her saving are not enough to buy it. So, S. has requested a loan to be used to purchase the land. On her new land she will grow crops for extra profit.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to rent.

texts.en:
Mr. Bora K. (was in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Sarath Nao, live in a small village about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1986 and have five children; one son and four daughters. All of them study in a local school.

loans.use: To purchase fish for resale.

Sarom is a silk weaver and her husband is a security guard. She is applying for a loan of loan of $300 to build a beauty salon for her daughter.

loans.use: To build a beauty salon for her daughter.

loans.name: Faaofo

texts.en:
Faaofo M. is 57 and married with 9 children (ages 12 - 35).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Faaofo has many years of experience in this business.  Faaofo needs a loan of WST $3000 to purchase additional crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2005, Faaofo joined SPBD.    This is her 5th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Faaofo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Faaofo M. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.4 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

texts.en:

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Vivian has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vivian joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be her 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un O. is a 38-year-old married mother. Currently she works raising a few pigs at her home, while her husband is skilled at making wooden furniture by hand. The couple was married years ago and they have two kids, one of whom is a minor and attends schoO., while the other one is a staff member in a restaurant. 

The family has difficulty finding water for their use because their house is located far from the watering system. They want to have a well but they don’t have money to spend on creating one. Therefore, Un O. is applying for a loan to hire laborers to dig a well for her family's use.

loans.use: To hire laborers to dig a well for her family using.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn A., 46, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Jose A., her business partner, they are blessed in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own eatery for quite some time now.

Evelyn has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her eatery.     

Now, with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 35,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business so she can buy the raw ingredients needed to continue production of her recipes.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide her children with a good, comfortable and well-off future.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients needed to continue production of her recipes.

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en: Marilyn L. is from the village of Guiwanon Panalsalan, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Marilyn is the group leader of a 2 member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Guava 1. Marilyn is married and has 2 infant children. Marilyn owns and operates a business selling daily use products such as sugar, shampoo, noodles, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Marilyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette T., 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Damaso T., an electrician, and they are blessed with two children. Managing her own variety store for quite some time now, Bernadette makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Bernadette has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and paying her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow ten times from CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her variety store.

Now with your help, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan which will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business to buy groceries to replenish stocks and continue the operation of her variety store. Bernadetter dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners gathering each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To replenish grocery stocks and continue operation of her variety store.

Mrs. Leam M., who is 38 years old, is a poultry raiser; additionally, she cultivates a rice crop. Her husband, Mr. Men Yoeun, who is 44 years old, is a firewood seller; he sells firewood that he cuts them from the forest. Leam M. has three children, all three of whom are students and dependent on her.

Leam M.’s husband borrows or rents his neighbor’s animal to retrieve the chopped wood from the forest as to he doesn’t own an animal or have the money to buy one. Thus, Leam M. requests a loan to buy a couple of water buffalo for her husband to use to pick up his firewood.

Mrs. But L. is a low-income person living in a rural area of Kompong Tom, a province of Cambodia, where she earns a living by rasing many pigs in a pigpen next to her house. But L. was married, but divorced her husband. She now has seven children, three of whom are married and live independentL. and the remaining four are single. Four of the children are employed at different jobs and provide their small income to help contribute to the famiL..

But L. is taking out her loan to construct a step for her house and will use the rest to accumulate more piglets for her pig-raising activity.

loans.name: Roeurng

texts.en:
The photo is of Mr. S., age 39, at his house. He is married to Vat, 33, who is a good homemaker. He also cultivates a rice crop to earn a living. This couple has given birth to four children who are now of school age.

In order to make a daily income, S. delivers rattan cupboards and firewood to sell directly to his customers’ houses. In addition, he has a knowledge that he uses to examine the villagers’ animals for extra profit.

S. has an old cultivating machine that he uses in his farming business; unfortunately his machine often breaks down during use. S. will be using his loan to repair his broken machine and with the rest he will mend his old motorcycle.

loans.use: To repair his broken cultivating machine and to mend his old motorcycle

loans.name: Jessie's Group

texts.en:
Jessie T. is from the city of Biray, Ozamiz City. She is 38 years old and is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Jessie is single. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products like soft drinks, rice, sugar, shampoo, etc., in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Jessie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mervin

texts.en:
Mervin G. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 39 years old. Mervin is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Mervin owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling used clothing or 'ukay ukay'  in the local community. Mervin has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mervin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mervin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mervin is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Mervin from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business
